Name: Vessel
Description: Small flask of marl clay, with flat base, broad shoulder, and a handle from the top of the shoulder to the middle of the tall, imperfectly preserved neck. The type is used for pouring wine in Greek tradition (oinochoe). This example was found at Memphis, and dates to the early Ptolemaic Period, when the city was still an important and flourishing trading centre, though Alexandria had become the capital.
